title: Update container-scanning to add default_branch_image to JSON report
description:
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
## Why are we doing this work

Currently users who run container scanning in a branch will see a duplicate of the findings that appear in the default branch instead of just findings that are newly introduced by that branch. We want to avoid duplicate findings for branches that are already present in default branch. In order to achieve it, a new [CI/CD variable](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/container_scanning/#available-variables) `CS_DEFAULT_BRANCH_IMAGE` will be used by the user to set the image which will be used to de-duplicate similar findings for the branch. The value set in this variable will be sent to GitLab Rails from [`gcs`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning) through the report JSON (`gl-container-scanning-report.json`).

This issue will address updating [`container-scanning`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning) with the field `default_branch_image` to the `location` object with value from the `CS_DEFAULT_BRANCH_IMAGE` environment variable.

[PoC MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning/-/merge_requests/2539) could be used as a reference.

## Relevant links
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5577)
- [Spike](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330641)

## Non-functional requirements
- [-] Documentation:
- [-] Feature flag:
- [-] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:
  - [ ] Test if the report json (`gl-container-scanning-report.json`) contains `location` field with value from `CS_DEFAULT_BRANCH_IMAGE`

## Implementation plan
- [x] ~backend Update [`Vulnerability#update_location_image_and_os`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning/-/blob/eacc9481/lib/gcs/vulnerability.rb#L75-84) to add `default_branch_image` to location  object from `CS_DEFAULT_BRANCH_IMAGE` env variable.

title: Add default_branch_image to security report schemas
description:
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
## Why are we doing this work

Currently users who run container scanning in a branch will see a duplicate of the findings that appear in the default branch instead of just findings that are newly introduced by that branch. We want to avoid duplicate findings for branches that are already present in default branch. In order to achieve it, a new [CI/CD variable](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/container_scanning/#available-variables) `CS_DEFAULT_BRANCH_IMAGE` will be used by the user to set the image which will be used to de-duplicate similar findings for the branch. The value set in this variable will be sent to GitLab Rails from [`gcs`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/container-scanning) through the report JSON (`gl-container-scanning-report.json`).

This issue addresses the updation of [`security-report-schemas`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas) to add `default_branch_image` field inside [`location`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas/-/blob/be9a0f80/src/container-scanning-report-format.json#L31-51) object.

## Relevant links

- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5577)
- [Spike](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330641)

## Non-functional requirements
- [-] Documentation:
- [-] Feature flag:
- [-] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:
  - [ ] Test if the new version of schema is distributed properly

## Implementation plan
- [x] ~backend add `base_image` field inside `location` object. The field should be of type `string` and it is not mandatory.

```json
        "default_branch_image": {
          "type": "string",
          "pattern": "^[a-zA-Z0-9\/_.-]+:[a-zA-Z0-9_.-]+$",
          "description": "The base image against which the findings are compared."
        }
```
- [x] ~backend Release a new version of security-report-schemas following the [release documentation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas#how-to-release-a-new-version-of-the-schema)

title: Cross DB modifications in Ci::Build within state transitions
description:
## What is a cross-database modification

Cross-database modification happens when data is modified in two different databases within an open transaction. This can cause reliability issues later when the CI database tables are moved to a separate database server. 

Example: keeping transaction open to wait for a 3rd party call (UPDATE query in a different DB) which cannot be rolled back anyway.

## Problem

The `Ci::Build` model implements a state machine where various state transitions alter the associated deployment record. 

### Offenses

The Offenses have been ignored with the `.allow_cross_database_modification_within_transaction` method. You can find them by grepping for the method name and the issue number:

```bash
grep -n "allow_cross_database_modification_within_transaction.*338867" app/models/ci/build.rb
```

See an example here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/ci/build.rb#L333

You can remove the `allow_cross_database_modification_within_transaction` block and run the test cases to see the actual failure messages. (`rspec spec/models/ci/build_spec.rb`)

Once the offenses have been fixed the `allow_cross_database_modification_within_transaction` method calls can be removed and this issue can be closed.

### Proposal

The `deployments` table will stay in the Main database so the update statements need to be moved out of the state machine's transaction. 

Options:

- Use the `build.run_after_commit` block.
- Use an async job to make the record updates.

Both options are less "safe". We're not going to have the same consistency guarantee as to the version with the transaction so we need to find the best way forward. Let's discuss ideas and the trade-offs in the comment section.

title: Packages changes to support the ci_* database decomposition
description:
## Summary

This is the resulting issue from the [analysis](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/336166#note_649492894) of the impact of the database composition in the Package "codebase".

Before the decomposition (eg. the `ci_*` tables will be in a different table), we will need 3 things:

1. [x] Remove the foreign keys from the build info tables to the `ci_pipelines` table
   * For future quick reference, the foreign keys are defined:
   ```sql
     ALTER TABLE ONLY packages_build_infos
         ADD CONSTRAINT fk_rails_17a9a0dffc FOREIGN KEY (pipeline_id) REFERENCES ci_pipelines(id) ON DELETE SET NULL;
   ```
   ```sql
     ALTER TABLE ONLY packages_package_file_build_infos
         ADD CONSTRAINT fk_rails_3e3f630188 FOREIGN KEY (pipeline_id) REFERENCES ci_pipelines(id) ON DELETE SET NULL;
   ```
1. [x] When a pipeline is deleted a the pipeline id in the build infos table is "nullified" (that's the `ON DELETE SET NULL` part on the FKs above). 
   * To have that behavior back, we will need two `has_many X, dependent: :nullify` in the `Ci::Pipeline` model. Why two? because we have two build infos objects: one at the package level and one at the package file level.
1. [x] remove the `has_many :pipelines, through: :build_infos` statement.
   * Replace it with a custom function that will break the join query in two:
      ```ruby
         def pipelines
           Ci::Pipeline.id_in(build_infos.pluck(:pipeline_id))
         end
      ```
    * Investigate a bit if we really need to return *all* pipelines or if the [first one](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/1ad294be8b96c45060aa6097375b78b33fce8018/app/models/packages/package.rb#L254-266) is enough.
    * Alternative (from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/338660): we can ask rails to disable the join query when dealing with a `has_X through:` association (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/67834#note_647234358). The resulting SQL is similar to the custom `pipelines` idea but would more readable.
1. [x] Update the `.includes` to `.preload` in order to avoid rails selecting using a `LEFT OUTER JOIN` that can happen with `.includes`. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/336166#note_655164671.

## Improvements

By removing the "direct" dependencies to the `ci_pipeline`, the Package code will not be impacted by the CI database decomposition.

## Risks

Build infos objects are used in:
* the REST API
* the ~GraphQL API (that also powers the ~frontend)

The risks are thus non trivial, although they should not impact the Package managers API.

Those risks are mitigated by the extensive test suite we have.

## Involved components

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/1ad294be8b96c45060aa6097375b78b33fce8018/app/models/packages/package.rb
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/1ad294be8b96c45060aa6097375b78b33fce8018/app/models/packages/package_file.rb
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/1ad294be8b96c45060aa6097375b78b33fce8018/app/models/ci/pipeline.rb

## Optional: Intended side effects

* Fetching all pipelines from a package object should trigger 2 queries (pluck + pipelines load) instead of a single one.

title: Improve the order of Vulnerability-Check Criteria
description:
## Problem

The current order of `Vulnerability-Check` items is a little hard to follow for the following reasons:

1. The number of Approvals required is listed right next to the number of Vulnerabilities allowed.  These are both number input fields and can easily be confused with each other.  Also the number of approvals is currently separated from the list of approvers.
1. Ideally the number of vulnerabilities allowed would be co-located with the severity levels that are considered.  This provides for a more natural logical flow in the user's mind.  For example, "I am allowing 5 vulnerabilities of severity Critical or High".

## Proposal

Provide a more natural flow with the Vulnerability-Check criteria by re-ordering the items in the order that they will eventually be found with the future Security Policies:

1. Rule name
1. Security scanners
1. Target branch
1. Vulnerabilities allowed
1. Severity levels
1. Vulnerability type
1. Approvals required
1. Add approvers

![image](/uploads/2267ec7ab22f90e2e60249c195278ba9/image.png)

title: Add timeout for Elasticsearch queries
description:
We introduced a timeout for count queries for Elasticsearch via: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/53435/

I would us to consider adding a timeout for search queries. This could help reduce load on the Elasticsearch server. We could show a similar timeout screen (similar to what is done with a Basic Search times out).

We need to take into account whether the searches are global, group, or project because the call to action (CTA) when a timeout occurs says to use the group/project filters and search again. Perhaps we should add timeouts for the global searches only.

The following discussion from !67977 should be addressed:

- [ ] @mayra-cabrera started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/67977#note_653254366):  (+3 comments)

    > Some questions about this class as I'm not familiar with it:
    > 
    > * How is it executed, is it async or sync? 
    > * Are the queries executed in the primary or the replicas?
    > * Given the elevated execution times, did we consider guarding it under a feature flag? 
    > 
    > Could you please expand on those? Thanks!

title: [External Status Checks] Remove default status for API requests
description:
## Background

When External Status Checks were introduced, the only possible states were:

1. Pending response.
1. Received response, which indicated [pass](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329636#note_654394212).

In other words, there was no way to indicate failure.  This was done for the [sake of simplicity/iteration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/327634#note_563430395).  API clients, as well as the API itself, assume that every request from the client represents `passed`.

A failure state was implemented later, under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329636.  For the sake of backward compatibility with existing API clients, the status parameter had a default of `passed`.

## Problem to solve

For the External Status Checks API, a default status of `passed` basically means, "when in doubt, assume the MR can proceed".  From a compliance perspective, we should assume the opposite.

## Proposal

For External Status Checks, the `status` param should not have a default value.  Requests without this param should receive a response of 400 Bad request.  This is a breaking change, as [discussed in a related issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329636#note_653730297), so must be made in a major release.

title: Investigation - Migrating Issues to Namespaces
description:
We need to investigate the work needed to transition issues feature to be tied to a namespace instead of a project. This means that issues should be available at the project and group level with minimal customization. The end result of the investigation will be a list of considerations, a backlog of issues and a high-level estimate of effort.

## Acceptance

- [ ] Iteration plan for moving `Issue` to `Namespace`.
- [ ] Improved performance for querying issues owned by `Namespace` and inclusive of issues owned by children Namespaces. (set benchmark and goals before implementation)
- [ ] Inclusive of WIP for Work Items. (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6033)

## Maturity roadmap

<details>
<summary>Available:</summary>

- A `Namespace.Group` and `Namespace.User` can create an `Issue`.
- Issue is visible in `Namespace.*` List and Board. 
- Issue detail routes are mapped to the `Namespace.*` where the issue was created.
- Issues from child `Namespace.*` are also visible in `Namespace`.
- A `Namespace.*` issue can still be closed/reference by an MR in a child `Namespace.Project`

</details>


<details>
<summary>Viable:</summary>

- Option to create a new `Issue` from `Group` `+` button in global header. See [1] (~frontend)
- Ability to select child `Namespace.Project` when creating a merge request from a `Namespace.Group` issue. See [2]. (~frontend required)
- `Namespace.Group` analytics include issues from `self` in addition to `children` issues.
  - VSA
  - Insights
  - Issue analytics
- `Namespace.Group`statistics include issues from `self`. Verify other `issue` counters return issues from `self` and all children `Namespace.*` See [3]


[1]:

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.17.28_AM](/uploads/532eec2110060ddf18a61d31fc7ec718/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.17.28_AM.png)

[2]:

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.33.30_AM](/uploads/5d56f28a9ea963dc25f83e1106bf6658/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.33.30_AM.png)

[3]:

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.41.04_PM](/uploads/f0247d2951053584fea47e424c34833e/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.41.04_PM.png)

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.42.03_PM](/uploads/884397cad45200469480a3f0d907d28d/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.42.03_PM.png)

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.42.26_PM](/uploads/e023356b9c29d28cf2a98a488ee9c3ec/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_12.42.26_PM.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Complete</summary>


- The `Namespace.*` is the default target for creating a new `Issue`. See [1] (~frontend) 
- Ability to disable `Issues` in `Group > Settings`. There probably should be a separate epic tracking parity of Settings and Navigation in `Namespace.*` (~UX / ~frontend required)

[1]:

Instead of requiring a selection first, default the pickers to the current `Namespace`:

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.15.53_AM](/uploads/7475afde651c06c1f948be86a4a45612/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.15.53_AM.png)

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.16.45_AM](/uploads/12d46711cbf0f4ff8eda8843d9f600c8/Screen_Shot_2021-08-23_at_11.16.45_AM.png)

</details>

<details>
<summary>Loveable</summary> 

- Ability to filter views by `Namespace` and/or the ability to show all issues from child Namespaces or only issues from current Namespace. (~UX / ~frontend input required)
- Make it more efficient to select the most probable `Namespace.Project` or `Namespace.Group` when creating new issues or MRs from an issue so a user doesn't have to paginate through a list of hundreds of `Namespaces` to find the ones they use most frequently. (~UX / ~frontend input required)

</details>

## Considerations based on the future ideal state

- Epics and Requirements will be migrated to a `Work Item` (Discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/332566)
- Promoting an `Issue` to `Epic` will cease to exist in the future as you will be able to just switch the type of `Work Item`
- A work item can have multiple parent work items. 
- A work item can belong to multiple `Namespaces`(https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/296668) or an equivalent technically feasible solution that allows for work items to roll up to parent work items in adjacent Namespaces and be visible within those Namespace views (Boards, List, and so on).

## FAQ

### Q. How do issues flow in the hierarchy? Is an issue created at a group level visible in child groups/projects or does it only flow up the hierarchy?

A final decision has not been reached yet, but If we had to make one today, it would work like this:

1. Worked items flow up a hierarchy just like Issues and Epics do today. In the future, we will figure out the ideal solution for rolling them [horizontally across one or more `Namespaces`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/296668).
1. A child `Namespaces` can assign issues to parent work items (and in parent groups) that are non-confidential. 
1. If a work item is marked as `Confidential`, it will follow the same permissions rules are Issues and Epics currently follow in terms of visibility.

title: Move rubocop in its own job in Version-App
description:
The following discussion from [!605](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-services/version-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/605#note_654028735) should be addressed:

@a_akgun discussion:

> 1. The links in the code quality section are broken, as they omit the namespace/project path `https://gitlab.com/spec/support/usage_data_helpers.rb#L3`
> 1. Related to the current MR, some long lines & extra lines - I wonder if we should implement a stricter rubocop in Danger Job for the VersionsApp.

@dstull discussion:

> I incorporated `rubocop` into codequality as it was an ability it had in attempts to ~Dogfooding codequality a bit more.

> I believe we have sufficient use of it now to say it doesn't work for rubocop linting the way we want it to since it doesn't have the ability to `hard fail`(looked into it previously) on specifically rubocop and thus can be easily overlooked as we aren't used to looking at things that aren't hard failures on CI.

> I would support breaking out `rubocop` from codequality and making it its own job for this project unless codequality items could be made hard failures by type.

title: Insights page takes a long time to load and returns an error
description:
### Summary Insights page takes a long time to load and returns an error `There was an error gathering the chart data` ### Steps to reproduce 1. Go to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/insights/#/issues 1. In `Select Page` choose Issue type dashboard https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/insights/#/issueTypes ### Example Project GitLab.org ### What is the current *bug* behavior? pages loads slowly ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? pages loads quickly ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![image](/uploads/1cee97bcea5144d9ad4b99279a43117d/image.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes Currently the graph returns data from September 2019 ![image](/uploads/25ef742e531b5d47cf04c055c70c9eae/image.png) Can we truncate this to show data by default for the last 90 days and allow user to view historical data in another page ot export to CSV format? The default should not be loading 3 years of data ### Additional considerations This limitation should be put behind a feature flag, so that self-managed instances can continue to run reports for 90+ days, while we have an option to increase the performance of GitLab.com. The default should be the current behavior (not limited).

title: Save the raw usage  data payload in a separate column in Version-App
description:
# Summary

Save the raw usage data payload in Version-App.

# Why?

In order to have available at any point the initial data we receive in version-app, this could be helpful in case of issues, to debug, and check if data is correct and what we expect.

# Details

We should always keep a version of the raw usage data payload as we send it from GitLab app.

This was kept in raw_usaga_data.payload columns [until we had to process the payload due to a bug](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-services/version-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/605)

## Requirements

- We should have available the raw payload we send with service ping 

## Proposals

- Add a new column `raw_payload` which has unprocessed data
- Save the raw payload, without any processing in the new added column


## Questions

- Should we copy all existing data from the payload column to the new column raw_payload?

title: Create a reusable vulnerability report component
description:
Currently, the vulnerability report is hard-coded to only handle the `project`, `group`, `instance`, and `pipeline` findings. We have upcoming work to show the vulnerability report in a number of new places, and it's becoming impractical to hard-code in every new type. We should rework the vulnerability report so that it's reusable and flexible. In general, we need the following:

1. Support for different filters that can be passed in:

```vue
<vulnerability-report>
  <template #filters>
    <!-- your custom filters here -->
```

2. Support custom header and footer content:

```vue
<vulnerability-report>
  <template #header>
    <!-- your custom header here -->
  </template>
  <template #footer>
    <!-- your custom footer here -->
  </template>
```

3. Support passing in vulnerability data:

```vue
<vulnerability-report :vulnerabilities="vulnerabilities">
```

## Implementation Plan

- [ ] Create a new `vulnerability_report.vue` component that's reusable. The current one does something like this:

```vue
<vulnerability-report>
  <filters />
  <group-vulnerabilities v-if="isGroup" :filters="filters" />
  <instance-vulnerabilities v-else-if="isInstance" :filters="filters" />
  <project-vulnerabilities v-else-if="isProject" :filters="filters" />
  <pipeline-findings v-else-if="isPipeline" :filters="filters" />
</vulnerability-report>
```

but this isn't very flexible because to add a new report type, we need to create a new component and add it to the `if`/`else` list. Thew new component should be used by the `<xyz-vulnerabilities>` components so that it's something like this instead:

```vue
<group-vulnerabilities>
  <vulnerability-report :vulnerabilities="vulnerabilities">
    <template #filters>...</template>
  </vulnerability-report>
</group-vulnerabilities>
```

- [ ] Add template slots for header, footer, and filter content to `vulnerability_report.vue`:

```vue
<vulnerability-report>
  <template #filters></template>
  <template #header></template>
  <template #footer></template>
</vulnerability-report>
```

- [ ] Remove `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/vulnerability_report_layout.vue` and combine it into `ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/vulnerability_report.vue`. At one point there was a good reason to have a separate layout component, but nowadays it's only used to make the filters sticky, which we can do directly inside `vulnerability_report.vue` instead of needing a separate component for it.

title: Investigate Pull Mirroring improvements
description:
Pull Mirroring is built over Import / Export and it may be time to reconsider the current architecture.

This issue is a investigation to determine what improvements could be made to Pull Mirroring to improve:

- performance
- resilience
- observability

It would also be useful to understand if Pull Mirroring is contributing to the [Source Code error budget spend](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6298).

The scope of this issue is to determine what could be done to help achieve these goals, including adding observability, tuning, code splitting or a complete rewrite. If possible, also to define and weight additional issues.

title: [Feature flag] Enable `zentao_issues_integration`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [Integration with Zentao](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/338178) on production,
that is currently behind the `zentao_issues_integration` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::integrations" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_ecosystem_integrations`
- Best individual to reach out to: @.luke (GitLab.com assisting @icbd from JH)
- PM: @lpeng1991

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## The Rollout Plan

1. Partial Rollout on GitLab.com with testing groups
1. Monitor Sentry for errors
1. Monitor Kibana and Prometheus latency for all actions of `Projects::Integrations::ZentaoIssuesController`
1. Rollout Feature for everyone

## Testing Groups/Projects/Users

<!-- If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example. -->

- `https://gitlab.com/icbd-trial/integration-trial` project
- `https://gitlab.com/icbd-trial` groups
- `https://gitlab.com/.luke/public-tests` project

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

The feature should be enabled with no negative effects to services. 

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

A very limited effect of high latency / errors affecting only the projects we enable for, and visible only when viewing ZenTao issues through the integration.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

See Rollout plan above

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set `zentao_issues_integration` true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set `zentao_issues_integration` true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature might impact the user experience, notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).
- [x] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> `zentao_issues_integration` true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set `zentao_issues_integration` <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set `zentao_issues_integration` <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set `zentao_issues_integration` true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can create a separate issue for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup ``zentao_issues_integration``".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove ``zentao_issues_integration`` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] (Note because the feature flag name is the same as a licensed feature, I believe instead of the commands below, instead we will need someone with write access to staging and production to run: `Feature.remove(:zentao_issues_integration)`
    - [-] `/chatops run feature delete `zentao_issues_integration` --dev`
    - [-] `/chatops run feature delete `zentao_issues_integration` --staging`
    - [-] `/chatops run feature delete `zentao_issues_integration``
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

Because the feature flag name is the same as a licensed feature, we need to ask someone with write access to production (like a SRE) to run `Feature.disable(:zentao_issues_integration)`

title: Track security scan report size in snowplow
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

Security scan jobs that produce large reports can cause performance issues and timeouts (e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331679).

We'd like to collect size information for scan reports so that we can introduce a size limit that will minimise impact to users.


<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->


## Relevant links
<!--
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.

- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>)
  - [Design 1](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
  - [Design 2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/<id>/designs/<image>.png)
- [Similar implementation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/<id>)
-->


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan
<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.

e.g.:

- [ ] ~frontend Step 1
  - [ ] `@person` Step 1a
- [ ] ~frontend Step 2

-->

1. [x] Add a new version of the IGLU [Secure metric schema](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/iglu/-/tree/master/public/schemas/com.gitlab/secure_scan/jsonschema) to include new fields:
   - `report_size`
   - `findings_count`
1. [x] Update the schema version in the [TrackScanService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/c6c3de5a62ec10e51eeb2777a04bf2009925e832/ee/app/services/security/track_scan_service.rb#L37).
1. [ ] Add report `size` to [`Security::Report`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/ee8f565ec9bfacf972a220743e77c6811c08d6c0/lib/gitlab/ci/reports/security/report.rb#L13), this should come from `ci_job_artifacts.size`.
1. [ ] Add new fields to [`data_to_track`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/c6c3de5a62ec10e51eeb2777a04bf2009925e832/ee/app/services/security/track_scan_service.rb#L37):
   1. [ ] `report_size`
   1. [x] `findings_count` (this should correspond to `report.findings.count`)
1. [ ] Add a histogram of report size to the periscope [Secure Scan Metrics](https://app.periscopedata.com/app/gitlab/895813/Secure-Scan-metrics) dashboard. The chart should use the `secure_scans` view and be filtered by the filters on the dashboard, i.e.
   ```sql
   FROM   [secure_scans]
   SELECT ...
   WHERE  [analyzer=Analyzer]
   AND [scanner=Scanner]
   AND [scan_type=ScanType]
   AND [start_time=daterange]
   ```
   See other charts on the same dashboard for other examples.
1. [x] As above for `findings_count`.
1. [ ] Using [Snowplow Micro](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/#snowplow-micro), verify that the metrics can be tracked locally. Note that the metrics will not be tracked if it doesn't conform to the schema or the schema has not been released.

You can also reference the Feature Proposal Template (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Feature%20proposal%20-%20detailed.md) for additional details to consider adding to this issue. title: [CI Minutes] Reroute purchase for personal namespaces to CustomersDot

title: [CI Minutes] Unable to purchase CI minutes for personal namespaces from GitLab.com UI
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

As part of rolling out https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5391 we discovered that the purchase flow lands on a 404 for personal namespaces.



### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->

Route personal namespace subscriptions to the in-app purchase flow

```
diff --git a/ee/app/helpers/ee/namespaces_helper.rb b/ee/app/helpers/ee/namespaces_helper.rb
index 84953beb59d..3edee0e9110 100644
--- a/ee/app/helpers/ee/namespaces_helper.rb
+++ b/ee/app/helpers/ee/namespaces_helper.rb
@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@ def temporary_storage_increase_visible?(namespace)
     end
 
     def link_to_buy_additional_minutes_path(namespace)
-      use_customer_dot_path = namespace.user? || ::Feature.disabled?(:new_route_ci_minutes_purchase, namespace, default_enabled: :yaml)
+      use_customer_dot_path = ::Feature.disabled?(:new_route_ci_minutes_purchase, namespace, default_enabled: :yaml)
       return EE::SUBSCRIPTIONS_MORE_MINUTES_URL if use_customer_dot_path
 
       buy_minutes_subscriptions_path(selected_group: namespace.id)

```

1. Ensure [feature is enabled](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5391#how-to)
1. Go to https://staging.gitlab.com/-/profile/usage_quotas#pipelines-quota-tab
1. Click "Buy additional minutes"
1. Greeted by 404

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

This was reproduced on the `rhardarson@gitlab.com` account on staging.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

<!-- Describe what you should see instead. -->

https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5391 should load and allow for a purchase


### Possible fixes

This bug was potentially introduced with this issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326663

### Follow-up

Once this issue is fixed, we will need to route personal namespaces to the new CI Minutes purchase flow. They will be getting routed to CustomerDot with this issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/338724

title: The ProcessRequirementsReportsWorker retries on an unrecoverable error
description:
I came here from looking at the [error budgets for Certify](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-certify/stage-groups-group-dashboard-plan-certify?orgId=1)

The biggest cause of spend is the `RequirementsManagement::ProcessRequirementsReportsWorker` failing and being retried 3 times. This worker seems to fail about 30% of the runs with an `Gitlab::Access::AccessDeniedError`. The past 7 days we've spent about 8 hours of compute running these jobs that cannot succeed.

| json.class.keyword: Descending                           | json.job_status.keyword: Descending | json.error_class.keyword: Descending | Count   | Count percentages | Sum of json.duration_s |
|----------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|---------|-------------------|------------------------|
| RequirementsManagement::ProcessRequirementsReportsWorker | done                                | Missing                              | 523,534 | 69.45%            | 87,031.19              |
| RequirementsManagement::ProcessRequirementsReportsWorker | fail                                | Gitlab::Access::AccessDeniedError    | 230,299 | 30.55%            | 30,303.60              |

(https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/44537aca483b44655c01d987e84e9fa9)

This error is raised from the [`ProcessTestReportsService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/be69d151b2e77226f0c401cea5600ef85983dc40/ee/app/services/requirements_management/process_test_reports_service.rb#L19). This kind of error does not warrant a Sidekiq retry, since it is unlikely succeed on a next run. 

Perhaps we could also skip scheduling this worker from the [`BuildFinishedWorker`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/be69d151b2e77226f0c401cea5600ef85983dc40/ee/app/workers/ee/ci/build_finished_worker.rb#L13) if it is going to be a no-op anyway?

### Acceptance Criteria

There are two changes to make here:

1. Don't retry this job if it's unlikely to run on subsequent attempts.
1. Don't schedule this job in the first place if it won't succeed. A strategy for this is detailed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/338717#note_653146872:

> So in this particular example, I think we could consider wrapping the [4 checks in](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/be69d151b2e77226f0c401cea5600ef85983dc40/ee/app/services/requirements_management/process_test_reports_service.rb#L15-L19) a method that we can check before scheduling the job.
> 
> In our codebase, we have this kind of pattern using a nested `Async` class, perhaps we could do something similar here?

title: Simulate accessing the wrong env (preprod)
description:
## Context

This is part of the work to upgrade and migrate the GitLab.com container registry to a new version backed by a metadata database and online garbage collection (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5523). This will be achieved following the gradual migration plan detailed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/container-registry/-/issues/374.

Before moving to production we will test a series of failure scenarios that were previously identified and documented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/runbooks/-/merge_requests/3628.

## Scenario

Simulate container registry being configured for the wrong env by accident. Test if it's possible for container registry in one environment (like pre) to read/write from/to staging or prod (bucket and database).

### Expectations

#### Impact

* Security incident
* corrupt data

#### Behavior

Leaked or corrupted data, application failures because of data inconsistencies.

### Test Execution

An SRE should manually try to connect from one env to the DB or bucket on another env.

title: Group membership export errors when group contains non-confirmed, invited users
description:
### Summary * Membership export to CSV does not work when the group contains users invited by emails that have yet to confirm their details. ### Steps to reproduce * Invite a user who does not exist within a GitLab instance to a group by email. * Export the group as CSV. * Fails to export. - [Sentry report](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/issues/2758420/) - [Internal link to trace](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/?_a=(columns:!(json.class,json.queue,json.meta.project,json.job_status,json.scheduling_latency_s,json.duration_s),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,key:query,negate:!f,type:custom,value:'%7B%22bool%22:%7B%22minimum_should_match%22:1,%22should%22:%5B%7B%22match_phrase%22:%7B%22json.meta.feature_category%22:%22audit_events%22%7D%7D,%7B%22match_phrase%22:%7B%22json.meta.feature_category%22:%22audit_reports%22%7D%7D,%7B%22match_phrase%22:%7B%22json.meta.feature_category%22:%22compliance_management%22%7D%7D%5D%7D%7D'),query:(bool:(minimum_should_match:1,should:!((match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:audit_events)),(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:audit_reports)),(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:compliance_management)))))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,key:json.job_status,negate:!f,params:(query:fail),type:phrase),query:(match:(json.job_status:(query:fail,type:phrase))))),index:AWNABDRwNDuQHTm2tH6l,interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:''),sort:!())&_g=(time:(from:'2021-08-17T08:16:00.000Z',to:'2021-08-17T14:16:59.999Z'))) ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? * An error occurs in the background runner and the export fails sliently. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? * The invited user should be included in the export but only with the available data. * No error should occur. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes The code here needs to be made optional: [Link](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/groups/memberships/export_service.rb)

title: Remove the commit form from Pipeline Editor Lint and Visualize tabs
description:
## 🧩 Problem

Currently the pipeline editor Lint and Visualize tabs have the commit form. The Lint and Visualize tabs aren't editable so a commit form doesn't make sense when these tabs are selected.

Remove the commit form from the Lint and Visualize tabs.

title: Marking an MR as "Ready" shows Banner with "can now be merged" even if approvals or merge checks are missing
description:
### Summary

When clicking the MR button "Mark as ready", always a message banner shows up with the text "The merge request can now be merged.", even when approvals or merge checks are still missing and the MR can in fact NOT yet be merged. The message is confusing.

<details>
<summary>Original bug report</summary>

### Steps to reproduce

* Create a Draft MR in a repo that has required approvers and successful pipelines set up as merge requirement
* Click the "Mark as ready" button in the MR

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The banner shows up which is confusing.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The banner could just be removed imho since it does not provide helpful information.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2021-08-17_at_15.50.35](/uploads/c6e4278d769e1fbdb20a6167fe4a2e23/Screenshot_2021-08-17_at_15.50.35.png)

</details>

### Proposal

- Update wording of alert to `Marked as ready. Merging is now allowed.`

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `create_vulnerabilities_via_api`
description:
## Summary

This issue is to rollout [Directly create vulnerability records via API](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10272) on production,
that is currently behind the `create_vulnerabilities_via_api` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::threat insights" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_secure_threat_insights`
- Best individual to reach out to: @Quintasan 
- PM: @thiagocsf 

## The Rollout Plan

- Partial Rollout on GitLab.com with testing groups
- Rollout on GitLab.com for a certain period - 1 week
- Percentage Rollout on GitLab.com - 25%
- Rollout Feature for everyone as soon as it's ready

## Testing Groups/Projects/Users

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-examples/security/security-reports
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/secure/tests/directly-create-vulnerability-records-via-api

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Enterprise users can create Vulnerabilities directly using a GraphQL mutation

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

1. Mutation can return 500 Internal Server Error
2. Vulnerability Report tab of Security & Compliance section can be broken

If any breakage occurs we can turn off the feature flag

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

Monitor Sentry for GraphQL errors

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status ecfbe63f221f06595a8f438f94bf2037b24899d8`
- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10272) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [x] If the feature might impact the user experience, notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).
- [x] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/secure/tests/directly-create-vulnerability-records-via-api create_vulnerabilities_via_api true`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-examples/security/security-reports create_vulnerabilities_via_api true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10272) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-default-enabling-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10272) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [x] (Optional) You can create a separate issue for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [x] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `create_vulnerabilities_via_api`".
    - [x] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [x] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [x] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `create_vulnerabilities_via_api` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-cleanup-mr>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/10272) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete create_vulnerabilities_via_api --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete create_vulnerabilities_via_api --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete create_vulnerabilities_via_api`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set create_vulnerabilities_via_api false
```

<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->

## Why are we doing this work

In order to add dropdown filters for image in issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337882, we need to support this filters in the relevant GraphQL query.

## Relevant links

- [FE issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337882)
- [Design issue](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation: 
- [ ] Feature flag:
  - `vulnerability_location_image_filter`
  - Feature flag rollout issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/340915
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan

- [x] ~backend Extend `Vulnerabilities::Finding` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/vulnerabilities/finding.rb#L4) with new scope `by_location_image`:

  ```ruby
  scope :by_location_image, -> (images) { where("vulnerability_occurrences.location -> 'image' ?| array[:images]", images: images) }
  ```
- [x] ~backend Extend `EE::Vulnerability` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/models/ee/vulnerability.rb#L4) with new scope that uses new scope added in `Vulnerabilities::Finding`, ie:

  ```ruby
  scope :with_container_image, -> (images) { joins(:findings).merge(Vulnerabilities::Finding.by_location_image(images)) }
  ```
- [x] ~backend Extend `Security::VulnerabilitiesFinder` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/finders/security/vulnerabilities_finder.rb#L20) `execute` method (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/finders/security/vulnerabilities_finder.rb#L20) with new method `filter_by_image` that uses scope defined in `Vulnerability`,
- [x] ~backend Extend `Resolvers::VulnerabilitiesResolver` (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/graphql/resolvers/vulnerabilities_resolver.rb#L4) with new argument (`:image, [GraphQL::Types::String], required: false`) and mention in the documentation: `when the image filter is present, the search implicitly excludes report types that don't support this location attribute`

title: Fix Ci::Runner#projects and Ci::Runner#groups doing cross-joins
description:
Extracted from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/336423 .

We have identified these `has_many through:` relations cross-join between `ci_*` and non `ci_*` tables which will not be allowed once `ci_*` tables are moved to a new database.

This includes the `assign_builds_and_projects` method in app/controllers/admin/runners_controller.rb

## Possible solutions

Ideally, we remove the relationships entirely. This will be possible once https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/72033 has been merged and we can replace the uses of these relationships with the new hierarchy tables

title: Future-dated amendments in Subscription Admin Page
description:
### Proposal 

This is a continuation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334426. We want to actually implement the UI to display information about future dated subscription amendments/versions.

Once the UX design is finalized in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337531, we can start implementing both the ~backend and ~frontend.

[Send Future subscription info thru seat link](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/issues/3800) is created to handle the CustomersDot's side of implementation.

![futureDated](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/8ea14d625706ff784c8aadce65443e66/FINAL.png)

### Requirements

On the subscription history table:-

* In the Name Column add a (i) info account with a tooltip that displays billing persons email address and underneath the company.
* Remove the **Email** column
* Remove the **Company** column
* **Valid From** date should use `starts_at` (no change)
* **Activated on** date should use `created date` of License file (this means blank for future subscriptions)
* We should not show non-cloud future-dated license subscriptions in the table. All non-cloud future-dated licenses should only be added by license file upload.
* Remove "Added on" column (if it has already been added)

title: Ignore Blur action types
description:
### Problem to solve

The Blur action (when removing focus from an element) is not implemented even though it is added as a Navigation Action. We have determined that at the current time it would be better to ignore these action types as they are rarely used to identify/find new actions.

### Proposal

Do not add the Blur action type as a navigation action.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

title: On Issue creation clicking "Select epic" does not bring focus to search input, causing problems
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When creating an Issue, clicking on the "Select epic" input does not bring cursor/focus to the Epic search input (which is the GitLab convention).  Users who expect the GitLab convention may begin typing.  They will lose that input, and it's also likely that they will type a shortcut key and experience unexpected behavior like focusing a different input or being taken to another page.

### Similar issues

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329251
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/300963
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292555
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/276086

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to a project that has issues and epics enabled.
1. Go to create an issue.
1. Click the "Select epic" dropdown/input.
1. See that the "Search epics" input does NOT have cursor/focus.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Clicking the "Select epic" dropdown does NOT bring cursor/focus to the "Search epics" input.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Clicking the "Select epic" dropdown DOES bring cursor/focus to the "Search epics" input.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2021-08-16_at_6.40.09_PM](/uploads/833943695cb622400851b26998657c54/Screen_Shot_2021-08-16_at_6.40.09_PM.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com.

title: Geo: Wiki HEAD ref not replicated
description:
## Problem

A customer noticed the `HEAD` ref was missing in some wiki repositories on a Geo secondary site.

When the `HEAD` ref on a Geo secondary site does not match the `HEAD` ref on the primary, it's not a data loss risk. But we expect wiki verification to fail in that case.

Geo did not need to replicate the wiki repository `HEAD` ref before. [Something changed recently](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/221159) and it seems we now need to that.

Similar to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334586.

## Proposal

It may be as simple as moving [`def update_root_ref`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d9fd807e4b5fea9b26bea54baffcbc804e00ce72/ee/app/services/geo/repository_sync_service.rb#L52-58) up to the superclass `RepositoryBaseSyncService` and calling it in [`WikiSyncService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d9fd807e4b5fea9b26bea54baffcbc804e00ce72/ee/app/services/geo/wiki_sync_service.rb) too.

We should pick the fix into 14.1 (and 14.2 if it misses).

title: Post-bulk-update submission toast notification
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

When the status of the vulnerability is updated through a bulk action, the customer should be informed of the change they've initiated. This information should be shared through "toast" messages as displayed in [this design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227284/designs/z_02_Details_Toast-Cases.png). 

Today we display only a simple text (which is declared [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/selection_summary.vue#L101)): 

![image](/uploads/6fc4bdea826d2112c671e494710b0ee4/image.png)

We want to specify also the state of the vulnerability. So instead of `3 vulnerabilities updated`, the user should receive a toast message like: `3 vulnerabilities set to resolved`.

## Relevant links
<!--
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.
--> 
- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227284)
  - [Design 1](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227284/designs/z_02_Details_Toast-Cases.png)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [x] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan
<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.

e.g.:

- [ ] ~frontend The i18n text is declared here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/selection_summary.vue#L101. We  'll need to update the translation so that it accepts a new state variable which can be passed here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/selection_summary.vue#L85.
- [ ] ~frontend For the dismissed state we also need to display the dismissal type as shown here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227284/designs/z_02_Details_Toast-Cases.png

-->


<!--
Workflow and other relevant labels

# ~"group::" ~"Category:" ~"GitLab Ultimate"
Other settings you might want to include when creating the issue.
